Package com.mssrchapelier.TigreParser

Class TigreParser

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.mssrchapelier.TigreParser.TigreParser
  • public class TigreParser
extends java.lang.Object

    The main class of the application which performs morphological analysis on Tigre words, as well as text fragments and files (with tokenisation). The application's public API is mainly (apart from the standalone command-line interface TigreParserCliLauncher) provided by this class.

    To perform morphological analysis, client code should instantiate the TigreParser class. The maximum number of analyses to return for each word (when calling the processFile(java.lang.String, java.lang.String), analyseLine(java.lang.String) or analyseWord(java.lang.String) methods) and the path to a configuration file may be specified, although both are optional. If the maximum number of analyses is not specified, all non-empty analyses will be returned by the methods mentioned above. If the path to the configuration file is not specified, the default value (#DEFAULT_CONFIG_FILE_PATH, which is res/config.json) will be used.

    The maximum number of analyses to show for each word may be changed after instantiating the class by calling the setMaxAnalyses method on the instance.

    • To perform morphological analysis on a single word, call analyseWord(java.lang.String), passing the word as the method's String argument. A two-dimensional String array will be returned: String[k_i][2], where k_i is the number of analyses produced for the i-th token, the individual analysis being a String[2], with the zeroth element representing the surface form of the word and the first element representing the corresponding gloss (both with morpheme boundaries marked as "-"). If some part of the word was not analysed in the k_i-th analysis, the corresponding part will be enclosed in square brackets ([...]) in the surface form and represented as "#" in the gloss.
    • To tokenise and perform analysis on a String containing a sequence of Tigre words (i. e. a sentence or another text fragment), call analyseLine(java.lang.String), passing the String as the method's argument. A three-dimensional String array will be returned: String[n][k_i][2], where n is the number of tokens that the input String was split into, and the n-th element being an array of analyses for the i-th word as described above.
    • To process a text file (i. e. tokenise it into words and perform analysis on all of them), call processFile(java.lang.String, java.lang.String)(inputFilePath, outputFilePath).

    All of the mentioned methods and constructors perform null checks on their respective String arguments using Objects.requireNonNull. Passing a null String to these methods will thus result in a NullPointerException being thrown, which must then be handled by the calling code.

    Passing 0 to one of the constructors which accept an int as an argument (which is the same as leaving unspecified the maximum number of analyses for each word since DEFAULT_MAX_ANALYSES is set to 0) will result in all non-empty analyses being returned for the word (by analyseWord) or for each token (by analyseLine or processFile), as mentioned above.
